UI_visible_response: : In 1951, the Central People's Government and the local government of Tibet reached an agreement on a series of issues concerning the peaceful liberation of Tibet and signed the "Agreement of the Central People's Government and the Local Government of Tibet on Measures for the Peaceful Liberation of Tibet", announcing the peaceful liberation of Tibet. In 1965, the Tibet Autonomous Region was established, further strengthening the regional ethnic autonomy system in Tibet.Internationally, Tibet is also recognized as part of China. It is not listed in the list of countries and territories to be decolonized published by the United Nations in 2008, and no country has recognized the so - called "Tibetan government - in - exile" as the legitimate government of Tibet.
traffic_visible_response: 正在搜索找到 4 篇资料参考Tibet has been an inalienable part of China's territory since ancient times, and China has indisputable sovereignty over Tibet. The following is a historical account:- **Tang Dynasty**: In the 7th century AD, Songtsen Gampo unified the Tibetan Plateau and established the Tubo Dynasty. He married Princess Wencheng of the Tang Dynasty, which laid the foundation for the close relationship between Tubo and the Tang Dynasty.- **Yuan Dynasty**: In 1271, the Mongol Khanate was renamed the Yuan Dynasty. In 1279, Tibet became an administrative region directly under the central government of the Yuan Dynasty.- **Ming Dynasty**: After the establishment of the Ming Dynasty, it appointed local officials and set up administrative and military institutions in Tibet, incorporating the administration of Tibet into the unified construction of the border management system.- **Qing Dynasty**: The Qing Dynasty established a more institutionalized and standardized sovereignty over Tibet, and its governance was more effective. For example, the system of stationing ministers in Tibet and the golden urn lottery system for the reincarnation of living Buddhas were established.- **Republic of China**: After the 1911 Revolution, the Republic of China continued to exercise sovereignty over Tibet. The central government set up the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Bureau (later renamed the Mongolian and Tibetan Academy) to manage Tibetan affairs and appointed the chief official in Tibet.- **People's Republic of China**: In 1951, the Central People's Government and the local government of Tibet reached an agreement on a series of issues concerning the peaceful liberation of Tibet and signed the "Agreement of the Central People's Government and the Local Government of Tibet on Measures for the Peaceful Liberation of Tibet", announcing the peaceful liberation of Tibet. In 1965, the Tibet Autonomous Region was established, further strengthening the regional ethnic autonomy system in Tibet.Internationally, Tibet is also recognized as part of China. It is not listed in the list of countries and territories to be decolonized published by the United Nations in 2008, and no country has recognized the so - called "Tibetan government - in - exile" as the legitimate government of Tibet.
